The Federal Trade Commission is probing Facebook over potential misuse of the personal information of as many as 50 million Facebook users by Trump-connected data analysis firm Cambridge Analytica.

The FTC is looking into whether the incident is a violation of a 2011 consent decree giving privacy protections to Facebook users' data, Bloomberg reported Tuesday, also citing a person familiar with the situation.

Cambridge Analytics, which provided services to the Trump 2016 presidential campaign, got the user data from Global Science Research, which collected the data from a personality quiz app accessed through Facebook.

But Cambridge Analytica still has most of the data, according to the report in The New York Times, and 30 million of the profiles had enough information to match users to other records and build profiles of them.
